About Nvidia
Nvidia homepage. Source: nvidia.com
Founded in 1993, Nvidia is a leading American multinational technology company renowned for its graphics processing units (GPUs) and system-on-a-chip units (SoCs) for the gaming and professional markets, as well as AI-driven solutions.
Besides being popular in the gaming industry, Nvidia’s products are widely used in data center, automotive, and professional visualization markets.
If you’re interested in buying Nvidia stock instead of shorting it, you can check out our dedicated guide right here.
What is short selling?
Short selling is a trading strategy where an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them on the market with the expectation that the stock’s price will decrease. The investor aims to buy back the shares at a lower price, return them to the broker, and pocket the difference as profit. It’s essentially betting against the stock’s performance.
Traditional Shorting
In traditional shorting, an investor borrows shares from a broker and sells them on the open market. If the stock price falls, the investor can buy back the shares at the lower price, return them to the broker, and profit from the difference. However, if the stock price rises, the investor faces potential losses, as they must buy back the shares at a higher price than they sold them for.
What are financial derivates?
On the other hand, investors can also short a stock through derivatives such as options, swap contracts, or futures contracts. These financial instruments allow investors to bet on the direction of a stock’s price movement without owning the underlying asset. Furthermore, we should also point out that even though derivatives can offer leverage and flexibility, they can also involve additional complexities and risks.

Step 2: Fund your account
Once you’ve chosen a broker, you’ll need to fund your trading account. This typically involves transferring funds from your bank account to your brokerage account. Nevertheless, be sure to deposit enough funds to cover any margin requirements for short selling.
Step 3: Open a short position
Go to the Nvidia stock page on your selected platform and tap on Trade. Pick your option’s expiration date and the strike price. Continue by inspecting the option’s pricing, risks, and other important metrics on the selection page. Then, determine the number of 100-share contracts you wish to purchase.
Lastly, double-check your trade details and swipe up to confirm the purchase. If you’re unsure, you can also save it as a draft.
Step 4: Manage your position
Once you’ve bought the option, you can keep it until it expires to potentially make a profit if the stock behaves as expected. However, if the market doesn’t go your way, your option might end up with a partial loss or become worthless upon expiry.
If you don’t want to wait until expiry, you can sell your option on the market. Simply go to your ticket, pick an order type (like market, limit, or trigger), set conditions if you choose a limit order, and wait for a buyer.
The key to making money with options is thorough market analysis, a well-thought-out trading strategy, and risk management. Options can be complex and carry a high level of risk, so they’re not suitable for all investors.

FAQs about how to short Nvidia stock

Can I short Nvidia stock with any broker? 

Not all brokers offer short-selling services, so make sure to choose a broker that supports shorting and provides access to Nvidia’s stock. A convenient option is to register an account with eToro, as it’s one of the brokers that provides the option of shorting stocks.




How much does it cost to short Nvidia stock? 

The cost of shorting Nvidia stock includes borrowing fees, margin interest, and any applicable commissions or fees charged by your broker.




What happens if Nvidia pays a dividend while I'm shorting the stock? 

As a short seller, you may be required to pay the dividend to the lender of the shares you borrowed. You should, therefore, make sure to factor in potential dividend payments when calculating your overall profitability.
